text: if they were in the election in June the
Conservatives say they'll curb
immigration to tens of thousands they'll
pledged to protect schools in England
from any losses from a new funding
formula but free school meals for
infants would be axed and they would
commit to a new social care plan winter
fuel allowance would now be means-tested
and for the first time the cost of
someone's house will be taken into
account in assessing whether they should
qualify it for state support to pay for
home care we can speak to the Health
Secretary Jeremy Hunt who joins us from
West Yorkshire right now very good
morning to you thank you for your time
this morning so we have a few glimpses
of a couple of things in the manifesto
some of them directly linked to Social
Care can you just take us through number
one the winter fuel allowance the
changes there who will still get the
winter fuel allowance well I will do
that but first of all can I just say
that what we're going to hear today is
two resumes plan to make Britain work
better for ordinary working families and
one of their biggest concerns is the
complexity in the social care system
which for many people is very baffling
and bewildering and what we're saying is
that everyone will have the security of
knowing that they can pass on a hundred
thousand pounds to their children and
grandchildren at the moment you can be
cleaned out to as little as twenty three
thousand pounds so that's four times
more and the reason that that matters to
people is because many grandparents
worry that the standard living of their
children and grandchildren may actually
be less than their own and so they want
to be able to pass on those savings that
they worked hard for all their life so
we are saying to pay for that there is a
trade-off and yes on the winter fill
payment that will be available for the
poorest pensioners those at risk of
going into fuel poverty but not for
other pensioners okay give us some more
detail on that then if you would we'll
come back to the other issue in
connection with Social Care in just a
moment the winter fuel allowance I mean
what what are the thresholds
well we are going to have a detailed
consultation if we win the election but
we are saying that it will only be
available for the poorest pensioners but
what we're doing by saying that making
that difficult trade-off is we're saying
that everyone can be confident that
they'll be able to pass on a hundred
thousand pounds to their children and
grandchildren that is four times more
than is the case for people who are in
care homes that are paid for by the
state at the moment so it's a big step
forward but we're being honest about the
trade-offs and if I may say if you
compare that to Tuesday where Jeremy
Corbyn is saying he's going to put up
taxes by 48 billion pounds and that the
only people who would notice anything
are the top five percent of earners when
actually we know that that would destroy
jobs for ordinary working families I'm
sorry on the time I'm just going to
interrupt you there because one of the
things you often complain about the
about you're the Labour Party is their

numbers I mean why can't why can't you
tell us how much do you have to have in
terms of assets in terms of what you own
to be allowed to have the winter fuel
allowance
but we're not going to give an exact
number today and we're saying there'll
be a consultation after the election if
we're successful but we're being very
straight that the winter fuel payments
now available to all pensioners will
only be available to the poorest
pensioners the people at risk of going
into fuel poverty it could be more
straight than that but we're not going
to give the exact cutoff so you're not
going to tell us that we eat but that
will mean that okay sorry to interrupt
again when I'm available for the poorest
pensioners I'm very keen to push on with
these numbers because this is important
so you can't tell us the actual number
that the the the amount of money you'd
have to have to mean you didn't qualify
so can you tell us how many people will
be caught up in this what are the
numbers of people who won't be getting
the the winter fuel allowance because
then we can add up the sums about how
much money that you will save to then
put into Social Care okay well let me
help you on that so that the cost of
these measures the cost of giving that
security to every family in the country
that they will be able to pass on assets
that they worked hard to build up all
their lives at least a hundred thousand
pounds is around two billion pounds a
year and that can be funded by
restricting the winter fuel payments to
the poorest pensioners as I say and also
by simplifying the way that we do means
testing for people who need state-funded
social care and you take those together
you raise this money we're being very
open that there is a trade-off and if I
may say I think that is what Theresa
Mae's leadership is about she's saying
that if we're going to make Britain work
for ordinary working families there are
no panaceas no silver bullets there are
difficult trade-offs but if we do this
we will have a simpler fairer system and
there's one other very big difference
about our approach to social care we are
not funding improvements to social care
by increasing taxes on younger working
is something that a lot of older people
worry about improve the social care
increasing too and we're saying actually
we're going to do this by reducing
entitlements for better-off pensioners
but actually that means that we can give
all pensioners that security that they
don't have at the moment where if a
husband or a wife gets dementia ends up
having to go into a care home paid for
by the state
you can be cleaned out of absolutely
everything by your last 23,000 pounds we
think that's an unfair system and we
want to change that by introducing this
new hundred thousand pounds that
everyone can be certain of passing on to
their relatives one of the stories we're
featuring this morning is the report

missed pledges from the last Tory

recently at the beginning of this year
so many of the pledges and bold
proposals that the Tories put forward to
us in the last election have not been
met why should we believe any of the
pledges you're making now well that is
not a an accurate characterization as
well what's been happening in the NHS we
have more doctors more nurses more
funding than ever before in the history
of the NHS you said you talked about the
ambulance service we're doing 2,000
emergency journeys every single day in
any departments we're seeing around
2,000 more people within the for our
target every day we obviously have the
pressures of an aging population and
that has put made it difficult to meet
some of the key waiting times targets
but at the same time you have an NHS
with record cancer survival rates the
biggest expansion of mental health in
Europe the biggest improvement in straw
and heart attacks survival rates of any
OECD country and you're seeing NHS staff
working brilliantly well despite
enormous pressure to deliver those
improvements the head of the NHS
actually said a couple of months ago
that in most major conditions outcomes
are dramatically better than five years
ago so the overall picture is of an NHS
that is doing more for more people than
ever before but dealing very valiantly
and courageously with enormous pressure
because we have around half a million
more over 75 than we have in 2010 and
that obviously creates pressure on the
frontline
